fields.description:
When {{git checkout}} is invoked on a LFS repository it will call the LFS smudge filter once per LFS file being checkedout.

Normally this is ok, it reads the file contents from {{.git/lfs/objects}}, however if the file isn't stored locally, it needs to fetch it from the remote.

The process per file is
 # Request the download URL over HTTP(S) from the remote.
 # Download the file from the LFS store.

However if the remote is SSH the process is far worse because theres a bonus step that the start
 # Request a Auth token over SSH
 # Using the auth token request the download URL over HTTP(S) from the remote.
 # Download the file from the LFS store.

Because of this each file can start taking multiple seconds to checkout.

If Sourcetree could call {{git lfs fetch <branch_name>}} before checkout then all the files that will be required for this checkout could be downloaded in parallel with a single call to get download URLs for all the files at once.
h3. Workarounds

If you are experiencing this issue there are a couple of things you can do to improve your speeds.

If you are using a SSH remote switching to a HTTPS remote will improve your checkout times massively as you eliminate the extremely costly SSH step.

If you are using HTTP(S) Remote you can open a terminal and run {{git lfs fetch <branch_name>}} before you checkout using Sourcetree and the checkout won't have to interact with the remote server at all.
fields.summary: Improve LFS checkout times

fields.description:
With an existing repo (well over a year using SourceTree with it) SourceTree loses the ability to create a pull request on GitHub.

When right-clicking a branch and choosing "Create pull request", I'm presented with this dialog

!image-2017-12-07-08-14-54-190.png|thumbnail!

 

The only way to get it working again is to hit the Settings button (or go into Repo settings), edit the GitHub entry, and click OK to save. You don't have to make any changes to the settings, just edit origin and click OK.

This is a private GitHub repo, using SSH. Extended integration is properly set to GitHub and nothing has changed with the remote. Once I go through the motions to fix this, it keeps working for a few weeks and then reoccurs. It happens while SourceTree is running, so it isn't a startup/shutdown issue.
fields.summary: Sourcetree loses ability to create pull request

*Expected results:*

local branch bcoe/nyc-cache should be updated

*Actual results:*

A new branch 'nyc-cache' is checked out.

 

This behaviour also applies to any git-flow-prefixed feature, bugfix, or release branch.

fields.description:
This behavoir usually followed, but there are a lot of exceptions:

Sidebar, right-click on branch name:
 * pull origin/master (tracked)
 * push to origin/master (tracked)
 * push to > origin
 * create pull request ... (immediately opens a web page)

Sidebar, right-click on tag:
 * Details ...
 * 'Checkout ...' and 'Delete' both open a confirmation dialog, so the ellipsis should be consistent

Right-click on a commit:
 * Rebase current branch to this commit

Right-click on file in 'Log / History':
 * Log selected...
 * Blame selected...
 * 'Open selected version' has no ellipsis, but 'menu–>Actions–>Open...' has one

Just to name a few.

 

Please decide if you display ellipses before showing confirmation dialogs and apply the behavior consistently.

 

See also: [https://stackoverflow.com/questions/637683/when-to-use-ellipsis-after-menu-items]
fields.summary: Use ellipses consistently to mark menu items whose action is preceded by a dialog

fields.description:
Currently, the context menu of any given commit line in the history view shows only the context of that commit.

However, the line often contains "labels", i.e. the rectangular boxes representing tags and branches. 

I'm proposing make the context more granular and also taking these labes into account.

 

Example: If there is a branch, it is represented via a label in a commit line. If the branch was created by someone else and has never been checked out to the local computer yet, the only way to check it out is via the Menu Repository->Checkout->Checkout New branch, then choosing the right branch in the pop-up.

It would be so much easier if the context menu were sensitive of the labels, so when right clicking on a lable it would bring up the context menu right for the label, i.e. with an enabled "Checkout" item that, when clicked, brings up the dialogue as descibed above and already filled it out with the right data (branch name).

 

Another enhancement to this is to enable a context menu on the BRANCHES, TAGS etc. headings in the sidebar (there is no context menu at all at the moment) that would present similar choices.
In the above example, the new branch is not listed under the BRANCHES heading. But a context menu would then show it and make it available for checkout.
fields.summary: Enhance context menu in history view with "label" context

I am running:
 * Version 2.3.5.0 
 * System Git version 1.9.4-preview20140611

*Update:* Same thing for 'Console Window Host' and 'sh.exe'

*Update 2:* Closing all instances of git via `taskkill /f /im git.exe` will cause Source Tree to crash so presumably these are caused by Source Tree and not some other software.

*Update 3:* Closing all instances of git via `taskkill /f /im sh.exe` seems to fix any freezing issues Source tree has (and causes elsewhere)

fields.description:
The font is too small and barely readable, or sometimes unreadable, and additionally appears to be distorted as if the entire UI was rendered at a different resolution and then scaled to the display size somehow. It looks incredibly bad.

 Below is the comment I left on this on community questions:

 

 Here's a screenshot of how a typical dialog box looks in Sourcetree (2.3.5.0 but the problem was the same in earlier versions).

In general everything is too small and looks distorted. It is very hard to read ANYTHING at all across the entire Sourcetree program.

Even in this one case, where I am allowed to choose a custom font for Diff (and Diff only), there is no way to even get that to render cleanly; there is weird distortion around every letter no matter what size I pick (see the sample text in the screenshot).

Why does Sourcetree use some strange custom font like this instead of native fonts in a readable size, especially ones with proper hinting for non-antialiased rendering.

Is there any way at all to fix this? It looks terrible and is makes the program difficult to use.

[https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Sourcetree-questions/Font-used-for-UI-is-unreadable/qaq-p/664605]

 

Had originally posted here but was told a month later that it was only for mac and to repost it here, but there seem to be many relevant windows comments in that thread anyway:

https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-1286

 * Enter the SHA and press *OK*

Even if I log in with gmail, I can not log in to my account when I enter credentials when I click the Clone button.
fields.summary: I can not install SourceTree (window with pass doesn`t appear)

fields.description: The Colors that mark changed lines (+/-) look to bright on my Monitor. Admittedly this depends on Monitor Settings, Monitor types - but if there would be a way to customizes These Colors everybody could Change them to Suite their Needs.
fields.summary: Make colors of diff marked lines editable

fields.description: The Colors that mark changed lines (+/-) look to bright on my Monitor. Admittedly this depends on Monitor Settings, Monitor types - but if there would be a way to customizes These Colors everybody could Change them to Suite their Needs.
fields.summary: Make colors of diff marked lines editable

fields.summary: Update Embedded Git fails

fields.description: With version 2.3.5 of SourceTree, when accessing large repos the git pull command and git push commands can both apparently hang waiting on something.  Waiting up to 30 minutes will have the item either fail (auth failure from what looks like a server hangup) or succeed.  However, generally both of these operations are in the order of seconds to complete when using the git command-line installed by SourceTree.
fields.summary: 2.3.5.0 has to use command-line for acceptable performance

fields.description:
Display again the name of the branch used for a commit in the "Log / History" view (summary area). It is very useful to be able to copy-paste the branch name that was used in a commit.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Display again the name of the branch used for a commit

fields.description: When looking at the commit description, tags are not shown in the description box.  They used to be before the UI rewrite.  It is very useful to have tags listed there, as they can easily be copied.  Also, we tend to use a lot of tags, and sometimes it's not possible to see all the tags in the commit history.
fields.summary: Tags not shown in commit description

fields.description:
Go to http://www.sourcetreeapp.com.

Scroll to the bottom and click on "Support" under "Resources".  It will attempt to go to https://support.atlassian.com/help/#/sourcetree.

That will redirect to https://sourcetree/, which is unreachable.

 Marking as high priority, because it makes it hard to find support or file tickets if you can't reach the page.
fields.summary: Link to SourceTree support is broken on sourcetreeapp.com

fields.description: The latest version of source tree can not be downloaded. I have been unable to proceed past the login screen. Previous solutions posted are not working. I tried downloading 2.1 with no success as well.
fields.summary: SourceTree install fails at login. Version 2.1 also does not work

fields.description:
INFOSEC enforces a proxy at my work location. When i press "Use an existing location" i get a blank window and cannot advance. I would like to be able to skip this step and move on. 

Calling the webpage on the browser works (meaning that for some reason this popup is probably not taking the proxy setting in to account)

I've also tried to install and earliver version, install my license and then upgrade. Unfortuantly this post install script will still force me press the same button.

Is there a way around this at all? Why would it not read the proxy?
fields.summary: Use an existing account comes up with a white page when behind proxy

fields.description:
Every few weeks commit text links configuration I have configured for my Git repository just disappears and I have to add it again.
Can this configuration be persisted permanently?
fields.summary: Commit text links configuration keep disappearing

fields.description:
I searched the Source tree Knowledge Base for information about the "fetch" feature in Sourcetree.

[https://confluence.atlassian.com/search/?query=fetch&additionalquery=more%3Asourcetreekb] 

When I search, although the product filter says "sourcetree", it shows me results for every product except sourcetree. 

 

Either no documentation exists on the fetch feature, or your knowledge base has its own bug. :)

 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 * Go to [https://confluence.atlassian.com/sourcetreekb/sourcetree-knowledge-base-265901498.html]
 * Enter "fetch" in the search bar
 * Press Enter

h3. Expected results

Only results for sourcetree are shown
h3. Actual Results

Results for Bitbucket, confluence, etc are shown.
fields.summary: Product Filter on Documentation doesn't work

fields.description:
After installation, when I have to login to my Atlassian account, the login-windows stays blank and doesn't load anything even after 20 minutes

 

I have had this issue now multiple times across various versions - this is annoying as hell and brought me multiple times to the edge of stop using sourcetree anymore, because it simply doesn't work when I need it the most.

Attached you find a very useful blank login page of Sourcetree   EDIT: Yeah, there is no attached screenshot because "JIRA could not attach the file as there was a missing token. Please try attaching the file again." Tried 4 times, screw all of this, it's just having problems...... :(
fields.summary: SourceTree cannot load the login-window - cannot use SourceTree

fields.description:
When staging files in the File Status tab, I use the keyboard to navigate up/down through the files and space to stage them. This workflow should be fluid, however after staging a file using space the focus is lost and seems to move to the appliaction menu bar at the top. Pressing down to navigate to the next file instead opens the file menu.

This should be a really simple thing, but it really ruins using sourcetree effectively for me when staging multiple files.
fields.summary: Loss of selection focus when staging files with space bar

fields.description:
When you do a merge, at some stage a popup with a list of conflicts appears (see attached screenshot). When that list is very long, you'd expect a scroll bar so you can scroll the list - but there is no such scroll bar. 

As a result, you can't see the conflicts further down. And you can't dismiss the popup, because the buttons are towards the bottom below the fold. So you have to use Git command line interface to deal with the situation.
fields.summary: No scroll bar on conflicts popup

Having to login each time and then explicitly have to tell the startup to skip the setup steps is kind of annoying. This used to be much better in previous versions if I remember correctly.

fields.summary: 64bit git on windows

fields.description:
Not always, but quite often ST hangs up without apparent cause. The application is not executing a command, but the CPU load goes up to 98% and RAM to 8-11 GB. It remains apparently forever in this condition, blocking all the PC.

The GIT repository open is a single repository of 6000 file and 50 Mbytes size. The app is still running but almost irresponsive, any command, even a simple tab switch, takes tenths of second. This condition seems stable,the only solution is process termination

Restarting the app sometime solves the problem, but only to the next startup

I attached two pictures of the CPU activity, the first showing the endless loop, the second the normal load when the bug is not present. Strange enough the second picture show the effect of clicking to enter the  File Status tab and going back to Log/History; the CPU load goes to 70% for 15 secs before returning idle.
fields.summary: S-Tree not usable anymore: 98% CPU load, 11 GB ram

fields.description:
When merging from one branch into another that would normally produce a fast-forward merge, git can be forced to create a new commit even if fast forward is possible.  SourceTree offers this option as a checkbox when performing a merge.

The problem comes in when viewing the log for these commits.  The diff in SourceTree should show no changes at all, but it incorrectly shows the changes from the parent commit as if the commit were not a fast-forward.  This can be very misleading when trying to figure out what is going on.

I can see how this could be considered a feature as SourceTree seems to aggregate all the changes in the branch that was merged, however it doesn't clearly identify that this is a fast forward merge with actually no changes in it and the changes shown are a representation of what was merged at a higher level.

Command line git properly shows that there are no changes on these types of commits.

 

Either remove this "feature" or provide a better label of what SourceTree is actually doing as right now it just causes confusion.
fields.summary: Diff is shown incorrectly on commits created when fast forward was possible

fields.description:
When merging a file remains selected in the staged area. This means that when you move onto the next file in the unstaged files the previously merged file has to be found and unselected in staged files to continue. This can be quite time consuming.

Steps:

Start a merge with conflicts.

Right click on file 1 resolve using theirs

Right click on file 2 resolve conflict options are all greyed out

Source viewer on right shows both files.

Unselect staged file

Right click on file 2 resolve conflict options are available

fields.description:
This has been occuring for some time, but had not previously been able to confirm it was not another git tool.  However, it can happen on a computer with no other git instances installed.

When trying to do complex activities such as rebase interactive, where the UI shows diffs of items, the diff refresh for the page can cause a lock file which can still be present when the OK button is pressed.  This causes the request to fail, and then the user has to do it again, at which time it can fail again (or as it is a race condition, possibly work).

 

This can impact adding lines, sections, or entire files via the UI as well.  Where the update of the diffs can still be occuring when the add happens.

By increasing the maximum diff size and testing with files with more changes, you increase the likelihood this error will occur.
fields.summary: Continual background diffs conflict with user requests.

fields.summary: Sourcetree freezes when clicking on cancel in ssh key dialog (Pageant)

fields.description:
We use SourceTree on several machines, and we've noticed all of them have started losing lots of disk space, tens of GB in some cases, to hundreds of 'bbchunkdl' files (e.g. 'bbchunkdl214143915' or similar) in the <User>\AppData\Local\Temp directory.

We have not been able to trace the file creation handles to a specific process, but we've noticed that their creation times seem to correlate with SourceTree Pull/Clone operations, and we've seen them created in the directory at the moment of a SourceTree Pull. 

All of our repositories use Git LFS, and with LFS being such a new and actively-developed feature, and the naming convention seeming to fit (bbchunkdl - binary blob chunk download?) it seemed reasonable to assume that LFS might be the culprit. 

These files don't seem to be used after a Pull/Clone, so is there any chance Git or SourceTree could clean them up?
fields.summary: Cloning/Pulling with Git LFS sometimes creates excessive temporary files

fields.summary: Can't install SourceTree

fields.description:
TLDR

1) Make the stash section into a grid for readability.

2) Allow selection and deletion of multiple stash items at once

 

I rely heavily on stashing for setting up local configuration and when popping items from the stash, I don't immediately delete them. It would be nice to be able to read the items in the stash more quickly.

Proposal one: add a grid system to the stash menu - currently the stash menu seems to store each item as plain text. It would be really nice for me if it was split so that one column had the item number, another had the branch it was created on, and another had the name of the stash.

Proposal two: select multiple stash items at once. Currently you can only select one stash item even when shift/ctrl clicking on another. It would be really cool to select multiple ones and delete them all at once. (I like to let my stash get big and then spring clean it!)

 

Cheers,

Xavier

 

The image below shows the lack of readability in a large stash:

!image-2017-11-06-17-30-23-792.png!
fields.summary: Grid Layout for Stashes

fields.description:
During installation process I cannot login using my existing Atlassian Account (which works when I login on the website).

After I entered my email and password the blue login button changes and shows a loading symbol (rotating wheel) but nothing happens. I cannot proceed and install/use the software. 

I tried a few times (yesterday and today) with different versions (2.3.1.0 and 2.1.2.5 and 2.3.5-beta-0).
fields.summary: Installation Login does not work
